text: The Great Pyramid of Giza is the only surviving wonder of the original Seven Wonders of the Ancient World.
The Great Pyramid of Giza was constructed around 2560 BCE and was the tallest human-made structure for over 3,800 years.
The limestone casing of the Great Pyramid of Giza originally made the structure shine like a jewel in the desert sun.
The Great Pyramid of Giza has three main chambers inside, including the King's and Queen's chambers.
The Great Pyramid of Giza aligns almost perfectly with the cardinal points, such as North.
Its construction involved approximately 2.3 million blocks of stone, each weighing between 2.5 to 15 tons.
Herodotus once wrote that it took 100,000 workers 20 years to complete the Great Pyramid of Giza.
Most archaeologists now believe that workers who built the Great Pyramid lived in a temporary workers' village nearby.
There are hidden voids found inside the Great Pyramid of Giza that are still a mystery.
The precise methods used to construct the Great Pyramid remain unknown to modern engineers.
Built to honor Pharaoh Khufu, the pyramid's original name was 'The Horizon of Khufu.'
The Great Pyramid of Giza forms part of a larger complex that includes two smaller pyramids and the Great Sphinx.
During medieval times, explorers believed the Great Pyramid contained treasure and dug tunnels into it.
Scientists discovered that the pyramid's interior temperature remains constant at about 20°C (68°F).
The Great Pyramid is part of Egypt's Giza Necropolis, a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
The Great Pyramid was originally covered in highly polished white casing stones that reflected the sunlight.
The Great Pyramid is aligned so precisely that it deviates less than 1/15th of a degree from true north.
Napoleon Bonaparte once spent a night in the Great Pyramid and wouldn't tell anyone what he experienced.
The average weight of a pyramid stone is equivalent to the weight of an average car.
The Great Pyramid's height was originally 146.6 meters, but erosion and time have reduced it to 138.8 meters.
The Hanging Gardens of Babylon are thought to have been constructed by King Nebuchadnezzar II for his wife Amytis.
The existence of the Hanging Gardens of Babylon is still debated as no archaeological evidence has been found.
The Hanging Gardens were possibly an advanced feat of irrigation and engineering.
Some historians claim the Hanging Gardens were built in Nineveh, not Babylon.
The gardens may have mimicked a lush mountain to remind Amytis of her homeland, Media (now Iran).
Hanging Gardens of Babylon were described to have plants, trees, and vines hanging in terraces.
It is believed the gardens stood 75 feet high and were built like an amphitheater.
The Hanging Gardens were described vividly in Greek and Roman texts, but no unequivocal mention exists in Babylonian sources.
The term 'hanging' comes from the Greek word 'kremastos' or the Latin 'pensilis,' which means overhanging like a terrace.
Alexander the Great's soldiers allegedly told stories about the beauty of these gardens.
The gardens are one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World whose location has still not been conclusively proven.
The gardens were said to be maintained by slaves using a system of hydraulic pumps.
Some believe the gardens were simply a poetic creation or a mythical retelling by ancient writers.
It’s speculated that the Hanging Gardens were destroyed by earthquakes sometime after the 1st century AD.
The gardens are considered to be not only an architectural marvel but also an example of engineering innovation.
German archaeologist Robert Koldewey claimed to have found evidence for these gardens in 1899, leading many to believe they existed.
Some recent theories suggest that the gardens may have been attributed falsely to Babylon instead of being in Assyria.
The Hanging Gardens are often depicted in works of art and literature due to their mythical and mysterious nature.
The Lighthouse of Alexandria was built by the Ptolemaic Kingdom between 280 and 247 BC on the island of Pharos.
The Lighthouse of Alexandria was approximately 100 meters tall, one of the tallest man-made structures for many centuries.
The lighthouse was constructed in three stages: a square lower base, an octagonal midsection, and a cylindrical top.
It is estimated that the construction of the Lighthouse of Alexandria took 12 years.
The Lighthouse of Alexandria had a statue of Zeus or Poseidon at its top, according to ancient accounts.
The Lighthouse of Alexandria was one of the longest-serving wonders of the ancient world, guiding sailors for more than 1,500 years.
The mirror inside the lighthouse was said to reflect sunlight during the day and a fire was lit on top for the night.
A series of earthquakes between AD 956 and 1323 damaged and eventually led to the lighthouse's downfall.
Parts of the ruins of the Lighthouse of Alexandria were rediscovered in the harbor of Alexandria in 1994.
The word 'pharos' has become etymological for the word 'lighthouse' in many different languages as a tribute.
It's believed that the lighthouse helped make the port of Alexandria one of the most important in the Mediterranean.
The lighthouse is depicted in various coins and manuscripts from the era, serving as an icon of navigational trial.
The Lighthouse of Alexandria was designed by the Greek architect Sostratus.
The lighthouse served dual purposes of a watchtower and a guide for approaching ships.
Some believe that the mirror was not used to reflect sunlight but to focus light onto ships.
Medieval Islamic scholars, such as Al-Muqaddasi and Al-Baghdadi, praised the lighthouse in their geographical and historical accounts.
In 1480, Sultan Qaitbay constructed a medieval fort on the very site of the lighthouse in Alexandria.
The Lighthouse of Alexandria is also known as the Pharos of Alexandria, which became synonymous with lighthouse.
The Colossus of Rhodes was a statue of the sun god Helios, constructed to celebrate Rhodes' victory over Cyprus.
The Colossus of Rhodes was approximately 33 meters (108 feet) high, making it one of the tallest statues of the ancient world.
The Colossus of Rhodes took 12 years to build, from 292 to 280 BC.
According to most depictions, Colossus stood with its legs apart across the mouth of the harbor of Rhodes; however, this is likely a myth.
The statue was toppled by an earthquake in 226 BC, and the fragments lay on the ground for over 800 years.
After the earthquake, it was proposed to rebuild the statue but ultimately abandoned due to fears that it offended Helios.
The Colossus was eventually sold as bronze scrap by Arab conquerors after they invaded Rhodes in 654 AD.
Legend has it, it took 900 camels to transport the bronze remains of the Colossus after it was sold.
The Colossus was built by sculptor Chares of Lindos, who was a student of Lysippos.
Some modern engineers estimate the statue required at least 13.6 tons of bronze and 8.2 tons of iron.
Despite being destroyed, the Colossus of Rhodes inspired many later large-scale sculptures, like the Statue of Liberty.
The Rhodians left the base of the statue visible, which served as a tourist attraction for ancient tourists.
The ruins of the Colossus became a celebrated fixture of Rhodes, attracting tourists who marveled at its enigma.
Ancient visitors reported that one could barely wrap their arms around the fallen statue's thumb.
The Colossus was funded with proceeds from the sale of military equipment left by Demetrius' army.
The ruins of Colossus remain undiscovered to this day, adding to its mystery and allure.
The statue was believed to have stood on the Greek island of Rhodes, near the port entrance.
Its construction was considered a tribute not only to Helios but also to the resilience of the people of Rhodes.
The Statue of Zeus at Olympia was a massive statue made by the sculptor Phidias around 435 BC in Greece.
The Statue of Zeus at Olympia was approximately 13 meters tall and placed inside the Temple of Zeus.
The statue was made from ivory and gold and depicted Zeus seated on an elaborate cedar-wood throne inlaid with ivory, gold, ebony, and precious stones.
The throne of Zeus's statue was adorned with sphinxes, intricate figures, and a variety of mythical creatures.
The statue, according to the historian Strabo, nearly touched the temple's ceiling, indicating the immense scale.
Olympia was the site of the ancient Olympic Games, held in honor of Zeus.
Zeus's statue was considered the masterpiece of Phidias, who had previously created the statue of Athena Parthenos in Athens.
The Greek philosopher Pausanias noted the wondrous detailing of the sculpture in his writings.
The Statue of Zeus was destroyed during the 5th century AD due to either a fire or plundering.
Coins and literary texts are the only surviving descriptions, as no copies of the statue survived.
The temple and the statue were both significant sites of religious reverence in the Hellenistic world.
The Olympics, which started in 776 BC, were originally a religious festival held in honor of Zeus.
It is believed that a massive earthquake destroyed much of the temple, leading to the statue's decline.
Phidias's workshop in Olympia was discovered near the ruins of the temple, indicating where the statue was constructed.
In the 2nd century AD, Emperor Hadrian was one of its notable visitors who marveled at Phidias's work.
The Statue of Zeus inspired many subsequent grand sculptures, influencing artistic renderings of gods and leaders.
Later, the statue was possibly moved to Constantinople, where it was believed destroyed in a fire.
The artistic style and detail of Zeus's statue showcased the peak of Greek sculptural mastery.
The Temple of Artemis at Ephesus was not only one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World but also one of the largest temples of its kind.
The original structure of the Temple of Artemis was destroyed in the 7th century BC, followed by a second version in 550 BC.
In 356 BC, a man named Herostratus set fire to the temple to gain eternal notoriety.
The temple was rebuilt and once again became a marvelous construction, adorned with fine sculpture and artwork.
The Temple of Artemis was dedicated to Artemis, the Greek goddess of the hunt, wilderness, and childbirth.
The 112 columns of the last version of the temple were 18 meters (60 feet) high.
Visitors would offer numerous gifts and sacrifices to Artemis and her statuary collection.
The temple served as both a marketplace and a religious institution, furnished with beautiful artworks and artifacts.
The temple was rebuilt after Herostratus' fire, only to be plundered by the Goths in 262 AD.
The remaining stones and columns of the temple were used later in the construction of other buildings and the Hagia Sophia in Istanbul.
Ephesus, where the temple was located, was a major port on the Aegean Sea and a significant trade and religious hub.
The site where the temple stood is located near the modern town of Selçuk in present-day Turkey.
The temple's location at the crossroads of major trade routes made it an extremely wealthy place of worship.
Excavations of the temple site began in the 1860s and revealed artifacts now housed in the British Museum.
It is considered one of the earliest and largest examples of Greek stone temples, influencing temple constructions thereafter.
According to accounts, the temple had a bronze statue of Artemis by Greek sculptors Pheidias and his school.
Visitors to the Temple of Artemis included conquering kings, as well as merchants, property owners, and travelers.
The artifacts unearthed at the site lend insights into the religious, economic, and cultural workings of ancient Ephesus.
The Temple of Artemis, in its various versions, stood as a testament to both human devotion and architectural extravagance.
The Christ the Redeemer statue in Rio de Janeiro stands 30 meters tall (not counting the pedestal) and is made of reinforced concrete and soapstone.
Christ the Redeemer was completed in 1931 and stands on the Corcovado Mountain overlooking Rio de Janeiro.
It is one of the New Seven Wonders of the World and is an iconic symbol of Christianity.
The statue was designed by the Brazilian engineer Heitor da Silva Costa and the French sculptor Paul Landowski.
The idea to build a religious monument on Corcovado was proposed in the 1850s, but lack of funding stalled its realization.
The statue arms of Christ the Redeemer stretch dramatically, reaching out to span 28 meters wide.
Christ the Redeemer's construction material was chosen to withstand Rio's extreme weather conditions.
In 2007, an organized online poll, conducted by a Swiss-based company, selected Christ the Redeemer as one of the New Seven Wonders of the World.
The statue is illuminated each night, creating a striking view from many locations throughout Rio.
It took nine years and a collaboration of multiple countries' expertise to construct.
Visitors can take a train, van, or hike through the Tijuca Forest National Park to reach the statue.
Christ the Redeemer has become a cultural icon, appearing in films, music, and as a celebrated image during major events.
A chapel is located at the base of the sculpture and is used for Catholic ceremonies and special events.
Each year, millions of tourists and religious pilgrims visit the statue, making it one of Brazil's most popular attractions.
The statue has withstood lightning strikes and even underwent renovations in 2010 to repair damage from weathering.
It has become a site of numerous stunts and events, including parachuting and base jumping.
The soapstone used for construction is sourced from the same quarry as the iconic Christ sculpture.
Christ the Redeemer is not only a symbol of faith but also a beacon of hope during times of adversity for many.
The Colosseum in Rome, also known as the Flavian Amphitheater, was completed in AD 80 under Emperor Titus.
The Colosseum is the largest ancient amphitheater ever built and could hold up to 80,000 spectators.
The Colosseum was used primarily for gladiatorial contests and public spectacles such as mock sea battles and animal hunts.
The Colosseum supports a complex system of vaults, which added to its structural stability.
It is estimated that over 400,000 people and over a million wild animals died in the games hosted at the Colosseum.
The subterranean levels of the Colosseum were equipped with animal pens and pulleys to raise animals and scenery into the arena.
The retractable velarium, a type of awning, provided shade from the sun to the spectators seated inside the amphitheater.
The Colosseum has undergone several restorations over the centuries, especially after earthquakes caused severe damage.
It is one of the New Seven Wonders of the World and a symbol of ancient Rome's architectural brilliance.
The Colosseum was built with funds seized from the Roman conquest of Jerusalem.
The amphitheater was commissioned by Emperor Vespasian as a gift to the Roman people to boost morale and fortify his political standing.
The Colosseum used a network of dozens of entrances and staircases to manage the movement of massive crowds efficiently.
The name 'Colosseum' is believed to have originated from a statue of the Colossus of Nero that once stood nearby.
The Colosseum was partially converted into a Christian site after Rome adopted Christianity as its official religion.
The amphitheater has served various purposes over the centuries, including a fortress, a Christian shrine, and a quarry for building materials.
It remains today one of Italy's most popular tourist attractions, drawing millions of visitors each year.
The Colosseum today is seen as a cultural symbol against capital punishment, advocated by the Catholic Church.
Every Good Friday, the Pope leads a torchlit 'Way of the Cross' procession around the Colosseum.
The Great Wall of China stretches approximately 21,196 kilometers across northern China.
The Great Wall's construction began in the 7th century BC and continued for hundreds of years.
The wall was built to protect Chinese states and empires against invasions by nomadic groups of the Eurasian Steppe.
Many sections of the Great Wall that exist today were built under the Ming Dynasty (1368–1644).
The Great Wall is not a continuous line—it includes defensive watchtowers, garrison stations, and signal towers.
An estimated one million workers died during the wall's construction, many of whom are said to be buried within the wall.
A popular myth suggests that the Great Wall is visible from the moon, although this is not true.
The materials used to construct parts of the wall ranged from earth and wood to bricks and stones.
Despite being called the 'Great Wall,' it is more accurately a series of walls and fortifications.
The wall served multiple purposes beyond military defense, including border controls and migrations.
Its construction leveraged the natural terrain, using mountains to provide strategic advantages.
In some areas, steep mountains provided natural fortifications, so walls were unnecessary.
The Great Wall crosses deserts, grasslands, mountains, and plateaus, each section distinct in construction.
Tourists often visit the Mutianyu and Badaling sections, which are near Beijing and are well-preserved.
The Great Wall's watchtowers were used for signaling and communication using smoke during the day and fire at night.
During the Cultural Revolution, bricks from certain sections of the Great Wall were used in local construction.
Some remote and rugged locations of the wall are nearly vertical, posing challenges to building and maintenance.
A lesser-known part of the Great Wall includes sections that extend into Korea.
The Great Wall has appeared in numerous cultural references, including films, literature, and games.
The Taj Mahal was built by Emperor Shah Jahan in memory of his wife Mumtaz Mahal.
The Taj Mahal stands as the pinnacle of Mughal architecture in India, fusing elements from Islamic, Persian, and Indian architectural styles.
Construction of the Taj Mahal began in 1632 and completed in 1648, with further works continuing for a few more years.
The Taj Mahal is made predominantly of white marble and features intricate carvings and pietra dura inlays.
The monument represents the eternal love of Shah Jahan, who was deeply affected by the death of Mumtaz during childbirth.
The gardens of the Taj Mahal are designed in the charbagh layout, symbolizing paradise in Persian landscape architecture.
The Taj Mahal changes color depending on the light—a different shade at dawn, noon, dusk, and night by the moonlight.
The Taj Mahal attracts nearly 8 million visitors annually and is a symbol of India's cultural heritage.
Shah Jahan was overthrown by his son Aurangzeb and spent his last years imprisoned in Agra Fort, with a view of his creation.
The Taj Mahal has been designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1983 for its aesthetic appeal.
The mosque and guest house surrounding the main tomb are perfectly symmetrical.
Twenty-eight types of precious and semiprecious stones were inlaid into the marble, including jade, crystal, turquoise, and lapis lazuli.
The minarets of the Taj Mahal are designed to tilt slightly outward to protect the main dome in the event of an earthquake.
British colonial officials once considered dismantling the Taj Mahal in the 19th century to sell the marble pieces at auction.
The Taj Mahal's central dome reaches a height of 73 meters and is its most distinctive feature.
The Taj Mahal is included in the New Seven Wonders of the World because of its iconic beauty and architectural heritage.
The iconic calligraphy inscribed on the Taj Mahal's portal was created by the Persian calligrapher Amanat Khan.
A myth suggests that Shah Jahan planned to construct a Black Taj Mahal across the Yamuna River, although there's no evidence to support this.
The architectural symmetry of the Taj Mahal is so precise that it reflects Shah Jahan's vision of eternal harmony.
Petra, also known as the 'Rose City,' is famous for its rock-cut architecture and water conduit system.
Petra was the capital of the Nabataean Kingdom, dating back to the 4th century BC.
The Siq, a narrow gorge that leads to Petra, is often referred to as the gateway to the city.
Al-Khazneh, or 'The Treasury,' is Petra's most iconic facade, carved directly into the sandstone cliff.
Petra was rediscovered by Swiss explorer Johann Ludwig Burckhardt in 1812.
The Nabataeans were highly skilled in engineering a vast network of dams, cisterns, and water conduits.
Petra's setting in a basin among mountains uniquely concealed it from Roman invaders, preserving its architectural wonders.
Petra contains over 800 monuments, including buildings, tombs, baths, funerary halls, temples, arched gateways, and colonnaded streets.
Petra had complex hydraulic systems that collected and stored rainwater, providing long-lasting water resources for its inhabitants.
Petra is considered one of the New Seven Wonders of the World and was designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1985.
The ancient city is nicknamed 'The Rose City' for the blush color of its limestone formations.
Nabataean art and architecture in Petra were influenced by Assyrian, Egyptian, Hellenistic, and Roman architectures.
Despite earthquakes and changing trade routes diminishing its importance, Petra stood resilient for centuries.
Modern visitors walk through the Siq to reach Al-Khazneh, enhancing Petra's dramatic arrival experience.
Petra served as a critical crossroads between Arabia, Egypt, and Syria-Phoenicia during ancient times.
The archaeological significance of Petra offers invaluable insights into the Nabataean civilization and their interactions with neighboring cultures.
Archaeologists have found evidence of an ancient Neolithic settlement at Petra dating as far back as 7,000 BC.
Petra's location and defensive positioning made it a vital fortress and trade center during tumultuous ancient times.
The Monastery, or Al-Deir, is another massive and impressive rock-cut facade in Petra, rivaling even the grandeur of the Treasury.
The Mausoleum at Halicarnassus was built as a tomb for Mausolus, a Persian satrap, and his wife Artemisia.
It was constructed around 350 BCE in Halicarnassus, in what is now Bodrum, Turkey.
The word 'mausoleum' comes from the name Mausolus and has been used universally to describe grand tombs.
The Mausoleum was adorned with intricate carvings and statues created by four prominent Greek sculptors: Scopas, Leochares, Bryaxis, and Timotheus.
The building stood approximately 45 meters (148 feet) tall, including its pyramid-shaped roof.
The Mausoleum was made of white marble and was a blend of Greek, Lycian, and Egyptian architectural styles.
The tomb was surrounded by a courtyard with a large staircase leading up to its base.
The Mausoleum's decorations depicted scenes of battles, including a frieze of the Amazonomachy, a mythological fight between the Greeks and Amazons.
After Mausolus died, his wife Artemisia completed the construction as a tribute to his greatness.
The structure remained standing for over 1,500 years until it was damaged by earthquakes between the 12th and 15th centuries.
In the 15th century, the Knights of St. John repurposed the stones of the Mausoleum to fortify Bodrum Castle.
Only the foundations and some scattered statues of the Mausoleum survive today.
A statue believed to be that of Mausolus himself was discovered among the ruins and is now in the British Museum.
The Mausoleum was considered one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World due to its grand scale and innovative design.
Its pyramid-shaped roof was accompanied by a chariot statue pulled by four horses, symbolizing power and authority.
Excavations of the site were first conducted in the 19th century by Charles Thomas Newton.
The site of the Mausoleum is an important archaeological location and is open to visitors in Bodrum, Turkey.
The Mausoleum combined architectural elements of a temple, tomb, and massive monument.
The destruction of the Mausoleum inspired later architects to create mausoleums in its image.
The Mausoleum at Halicarnassus is an enduring symbol of Hellenistic artistic and engineering achievement.
Machu Picchu is an ancient Inca city located in the Andes Mountains of Peru.
It was built in the 15th century during the reign of the Inca emperor Pachacuti.
The site is perched 2,430 meters (7,970 feet) above sea level on a mountain ridge.
Machu Picchu was rediscovered by American explorer Hiram Bingham in 1911.
It is often referred to as the 'Lost City of the Incas' because it remained hidden from the outside world for centuries.
The purpose of Machu Picchu remains uncertain but is believed to have served as a royal estate or religious retreat.
The Intihuatana Stone, found at Machu Picchu, is thought to have been a solar clock or calendar for agricultural purposes.
Machu Picchu features over 200 buildings, including temples, residences, and storage houses.
The Terraces of Machu Picchu were used for farming and also prevented soil erosion.
Its finely crafted walls were built using a technique called ashlar masonry, where stones are fitted together without mortar.
Machu Picchu is surrounded by the lush green Urubamba River Valley, creating a stunning natural backdrop.
The site's main structures include the Temple of the Sun, the Room of the Three Windows, and the Main Temple.
Machu Picchu is considered one of humanity's greatest architectural and cultural achievements.
It was declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1983 and one of the New Seven Wonders of the World in 2007.
The population at Machu Picchu during its peak was estimated to be around 750 people.
Machu Picchu is located above the Sacred Valley, a region rich with Inca history and culture.
The network of trails leading to Machu Picchu is known as the Inca Trail, a popular trek for tourists.
Machu Picchu remained unknown to the Spanish conquistadors, which contributed to its preservation.
It was constructed with a sophisticated drainage system to handle heavy rainfall in the Andes.
Machu Picchu is considered both a historical and natural treasure, combining ancient architecture and biodiversity.
Chichen Itza is a Mayan archaeological site located in Yucatan, Mexico.
El Castillo, also known as the Temple of Kukulcan, is Chichen Itza’s most famous structure.
The pyramid of El Castillo has 91 steps on each of its four sides, plus the top platform, totaling 365 steps to represent the solar year.
During the equinoxes, the sun creates the illusion of a serpent slithering down El Castillo's steps.
Chichen Itza was a major political and economic center of the Mayan civilization from 600 to 1200 AD.
The Great Ball Court at Chichen Itza is the largest in Mesoamerica, measuring 168 by 70 meters (551 by 230 feet).
Players of the Mayan ballgame used their hips to hit a rubber ball through stone rings mounted high on the court walls.
Human sacrifices were part of Chichen Itza's religious rituals, and offerings were often thrown into the Sacred Cenote.
The term Chichen Itza means 'At the mouth of the well of the Itza,' referring to the site's cenotes (natural sinkholes).
The Temple of the Warriors at Chichen Itza is a large stepped pyramid surrounded by hundreds of carved columns.
The cenotes at Chichen Itza provided water for the city's inhabitants and played a significant role in Mayan ceremonies.
Chichen Itza shows a mix of Mayan and Toltec architectural styles, reflecting cultural interaction between the two groups.
The Observatory, or El Caracol, at Chichen Itza was used for astronomical purposes.
Chichen Itza was declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1988 and is one of the New Seven Wonders of the World.
The site includes a platform called Tzompantli, or the Skull Platform, which was used to display the heads of sacrificed individuals.
The Wall of the Skulls at Chichen Itza hints at the site's significance as a religious and political center.
Chichen Itza is situated in a region where cenotes made it possible to sustain large populations despite the arid landscape.
The Columned Hall of a Thousand Columns may have served as a meeting place or marketplace.
El Castillo depicts the feathered serpent god Kukulcan, a vital deity in Mayan mythology.
Chichen Itza illustrates the advanced mathematical, engineering, and astronomical skills of the Mayans.
